title: Private vs Public Ghost Tours
content:
If you've ever stood at the back of a large ghost tour group struggling to hear the guide, you've probably wondered whether a private ghost tour would be worth the extra money. I've asked myself that question many times—and the answer isn't as simple as "private is better." After taking both formats in the same cities, I've learned that the real difference comes down to group dynamics, flexibility, and what you want out of the experience.

What's the difference between private and public tours?

Public ghost tours follow a fixed route with a mixed group of strangers. They're designed for accessibility and efficiency, with guides keeping to a schedule that works for everyone. Private ghost tours, on the other hand, are reserved for a single group. The route, pacing, and tone can often be adjusted, and guides are free to answer questions without worrying about time pressure from a larger crowd.

When are private tours worth the cost?

Private tours are worth considering when personalization matters more than price. This includes anniversaries, small group travel, photography-focused outings, or situations where accessibility or pacing needs special attention. In my experience, private tours shine when you want deeper discussion or when one location deserves more time than a standard tour allows. They're also valuable when traveling with kids or people who have very different comfort levels with paranormal topics.

When are public tours the better choice?

Public tours are ideal for first-time visitors and solo travelers. They're affordable, easy to book, and provide a broad overview without requiring advance coordination. Public tours also work well in cities with a strong guide culture, where storytelling quality is consistent across multiple operators. For most travelers, a well-reviewed public tour delivers excellent value. Our guide on how to spot a bad ghost tour helps identify quality options.

How much more do private tours cost?

Private ghost tours typically cost more upfront but can become cost-effective for groups. Public tours often range from $25 to $45 per person, while private tours usually start around $150 to $300 per group, depending on city and duration. For groups of four to six people, the per-person cost difference can be smaller than expected—especially when customization is factored in.

What can you customize on private tours?

Customization varies by operator but often includes start time, route emphasis, pacing, and topic focus. Some guides adjust content toward history, architecture, or paranormal investigation based on group interest. I've had private tours pause longer at specific sites, skip crowded stops, or shift tone mid-tour—options that simply aren't possible with large public groups. Photography enthusiasts particularly benefit from this flexibility.

Private options by tour format

Most tour formats offer private versions:
  • Walking tours – Most commonly available as private options
  • Investigation tours – Private investigations allow use of all equipment without sharing
  • Cemetery tours – Private visits feel more contemplative and personal
  • Pub crawls – Private versions can adjust drinking pace and bar selection

Best cities for private ghost tours

Cities with competitive tour markets offer the best private options:
  • New Orleans – Excellent private courtyard and interior access
  • Savannah – Intimate scale perfect for private exploration
  • Edinburgh – Private vault access available
  • London – After-hours access to historic pubs and locations

How do you book a private tour?

Most operators list private options alongside public tours. Look for clear descriptions that explain what's included and what can be customized. Booking early matters more for private tours, especially in popular cities or during peak travel seasons.

Practical Takeaway

Private ghost tours offer flexibility and depth, while public tours offer efficiency and value. Neither is inherently better—the right choice depends on group size, goals, and budget. For couples considering a more intimate experience, private tours often justify the cost. Skeptics may also appreciate the ability to ask deeper questions without group pressure.
